title: Critical Care Pain Observation Tool (CPOT)
description: Pain assessment tool for critically ill adults who are unable to self-report pain, using behavioral indicators across four domains

parameters.name: facial_expression
parameters.description: Facial expression assessment - observational scoring of facial muscle tension and movements

parameters.name: body_movements
parameters.description: Body movements assessment - observational scoring of patient movement patterns and protective behaviors

parameters.name: muscle_tension
parameters.description: Muscle tension assessment - evaluation of resistance to passive movements

parameters.name: patient_status
parameters.description: Patient intubation status - determines which assessment domain to use (ventilator compliance vs vocalization)

parameters.name: ventilator_compliance
parameters.description: Compliance with ventilator (for intubated patients only) - assessment of patient tolerance of mechanical ventilation

parameters.name: vocalization
parameters.description: Vocalization (for extubated patients only) - assessment of verbal and vocal expressions of pain

result.name: cpot_score
result.description: Total CPOT score ranging from 0-8 points based on behavioral pain indicators

ranges.interpretation: CPOT score ≤2 indicates minimal to no pain. Continue current pain management plan and routine monitoring.
CPOT score >2 indicates unacceptable pain level. Consider alternative analgesia, reassess pain management plan, and provide non-pharmacological comfort measures.

references: Gélinas C, Fillion L, Puntillo KA, Viens C, Fortier M. Validation of the critical-care pain observation tool in adult patients. Am J Crit Care. 2006;15(4):420-427.

Gélinas C, Harel F, Fillion L, Puntillo KA, Johnston CC. Sensitivity and specificity of the critical-care pain observation tool for the detection of pain in intubated adults after cardiac surgery. J Pain Symptom Manage. 2009;37(1):58-67.
Payen JF, Bru O, Bosson JL, et al. Assessing pain in critically ill sedated patients by using a behavioral pain scale. Crit Care Med. 2001;29(12):2258-2263.
formula: Sum of individual domain scores: Facial Expression (0-2) + Body Movements (0-2) + Muscle Tension (0-2) + Ventilator Compliance OR Vocalization (0-2)
notes: Designed for critically ill adults who cannot self-report pain
Observe patient at rest for 60 seconds before scoring
Use ventilator compliance domain for intubated patients, vocalization domain for extubated patients
Validated for use in conscious and unconscious ICU patients
Part of the ABCDEF bundle for ICU pain management
Should be used in conjunction with clinical assessment and other pain indicators
Reassess after pain interventions to evaluate effectiveness
